facts.text: Criminal Appeal 229 of 1969 is an appeal by certificate from the judgment and order dated October 9, 1969 of the Bombay High Court in Cr. A. No. 727 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal 229 of 1969. Appeal by certificate from the judgment and order dated October 9, 1969 of the Bombay High Court in Cr. A. No. 727 of 1967. M. Mistry and Vineet Kumar, for the C. Bhandare and B. D. Sharma and S. P. Nayar, for the respondent.

facts.text: The High Court convicted the appellant under sections 161 and 385 of the Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: from the judgment dated 8 and 9 October, 1969 of the High Court at Bombay company- victing the appellant under sections 161 and 385 of he Indian Penal Code. The High Court companyfirmed the substantive sentence to simple imprisonment for six months under section 161 of the Indian Penal Code and simple imprisonment for three months under section 385 of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: The High Court confirmed the substantive sentence to simple imprisonment for six months under section 161 IPC and three months under section 385 IPC, and imposed a fine of Rs. 10,000 with further six months imprisonment in default.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court companyfirmed the substantive sentence to simple imprisonment for six months under section 161 of the Indian Penal Code and simple imprisonment for three months under section 385 of the Indian Penal Code. In addition, the High Court imposed on the appellant a fine of Rs. 10,000 and in default of payments of fine, further simple imprisonment for six months.

facts.text: The appellant was the Coroner of Bombay at the crucial time.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was at the crucial time the Coroner of Bombay. The prosecution case was as follows. Jagdish prasad Ram- narayan Khandelwal was admitted to the nursing home of a Gynecologist Dr. Adatia on 3 May, 1964.

facts.text: Jagdish Prasad Ramnarayan Khandelwal was admitted to the nursing home of Dr. Adatia on 3 May 1964.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution case was as follows. Jagdish prasad Ram- narayan Khandelwal was admitted to the nursing home of a Gynecologist Dr. Adatia on 3 May, 1964. Dr. Adatia diag- numbered the case as acute appendicitis.

facts.text: Dr. Adatia diagnosed the case as acute appendicitis and kept the patient under observation.

anchor.surface_text: Dr. Adatia diag- numbered the case as acute appendicitis. Dr. Adatia kept the patient under observation. After 24 hours the companydition of the patient became serious.

facts.text: The patient died on 13 May 1964.

anchor.surface_text: The patient died on 13 May, 1964. The Hospital issued a Death Intimation Card as paralytic ileus and peritonitis following an operation, for acute appendicitis.

facts.text: The Hospital issued a Death Intimation Card as paralytic ileus and peritonitis following an operation for acute appendicitis.

anchor.surface_text: The Hospital issued a Death Intimation Card as paralytic ileus and peritonitis following an operation, for acute appendicitis. The appellant allowed the disposal of the dead body without ordering post-mortem.

facts.text: Coroners Court registered the inquest on 13 May 1964.

anchor.surface_text: The Coroners Court registered the inquest on 13 May, 1964. The dates for inquest were in the months of June, July, September and October, 1964.

facts.text: The appellant on 3 October 1964 made an order that Mr. Adatia be called.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant on 3 October, 1964 made an order that Mr. Adatia be called. It is alleged that the appellant had told Dr. Adatia a ,few days earlier that though he might have operated satisfactorily the cause of death given by the hospital would give rise to a presumption of negligence on his part.

facts.text: Dr. Motwani met the appellant on 3 October 1964 and the appellant demanded Rs. 20,000.

anchor.surface_text: Dr. Motwani met the appellant on 3 October, 1964. The appellant told Dr. Motwani that Dr. Adatia was at fault but he might be cleared of the charge in the inquest. The appellant asked for a sum of Rs. 20,000.

facts.text: Dr. Adatia refused to pay Rs. 20,000 and later Rs. 10,000 demanded by the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Dr. Motwani companyveyed the proposal to Dr. Adatia. The latter refused to pay any illegal gratification. Dr. Motwani intimated the same to the appellant. The appellant then reduced the demand to Rs. 10,000.

facts.text: On 5 October 1964 Dr. Motwani and Dr. Adatia decided to lodge a complaint with the Anti Corruption Bureau.

anchor.surface_text: On 5 October, 1964 Dr. Motwani and Dr Adatia decided to lodge a companyplaint with the Anti Corruption Bureau. Dr. Adatias Nursing Home got messages on the telephone to get in touch with the appellant.

facts.text: On 7 October 1964 Mugwe and Assistant Commissioner Sawant went to Dr. Motwani's residence with tape recording equipment.

anchor.surface_text: On 7 October 1964 Mugwe and the Assistant Commissioner of Police Sawant went to Dr. Motwanis residence. They met Dr. Motwani and Dr. Adatia. When they companymenced recording the First Information Report of Dr. Motwani, Dr. Adatia left for his Nursing Home.

facts.text: Tape recorded conversation between Dr. Motwani and the appellant on 7 October 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Mugwe then arranged for the tape recording equipment to be attached to the telephone of Dr. Motwani. Dr. Motwani was asked by Mugwe to ring up the appellant in the presence of Mugwe and other Police Officers about the appellants demand for the money.

facts.text: The two doctors met the appellant on 7 October 1964 at 12 noon in Coroner's Chamber and appellant raised demand to Rs. 15,000.

anchor.surface_text: The two Doctors Motwani and Adatia met the appellant in the Coroners Chamber at 12 numbern. The appellant raised the demand to Rs. 15,000 and said that Rs. 5,000 was to he paid to Coroners Surgeon for giving an opinion in favour of Dr. Adatia.

facts.text: Dr. Adatia agreed to pay Rs. 15,000 to appellant on 9 October 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Dr. Adatia then told the appellant that lie would pay the appellant Rs. 15,000 on 9 October, 1964. Dr. Adatia paid Rs. 15,000 to Dr. Motwani.

facts.text: The appellant was charged under sections 161, 385 and 420 read with section 511 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was charged under sections 161, 385 and 420 read with section 511 of the Indian Penal Code. Broadly stated, the charges against the appellant were these.

facts.text: The appellant denied that he demanded any amount through Dr. Motwani and denied threatening Dr. Adatia.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant denied that he demanded any amount through Dr. Motwani. He also denied that he threatened Dr. Adatia  if the companysequence of an inquest.

facts.text: Trial Court and High Court found that evidence of Dr. Motwani and Dr. Adatia needed corroboration, provided by tape conversation.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Court as well as the High Court found that the evidence of Dr. Motwani and Dr. Adatia needed companyroboration. The High Court found that the companyversation recorded on the tape companyroborated their evidence.

facts.text: The Supreme Court held the tape recorded conversation admissible in evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The tape recorded companyversation is admissible in evidence.  1  1971 1 S C. R. 399.  2  1967 3 S.C.R. 720  3  1964 4 S.C.R. 733. It was said by companynsel for the appellant that the tape recorded companyversation was obtained by illegal means.

facts.text: The appeal is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons, the appeal is dismissed.

The evidence was illegally obtained in contravention of section 25 of the Indian Telegraph Act and therefore the evidence was inadmissible. Secondly, the conversation between Dr. Motwani and the appellant which was recorded on the tape took place during investigation inasmuch as Mugwe asked Dr. Motwani to talk and therefore the conversation was not admissible under section 162 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

anchor.surface_text: Telegraph is defined in the Indian Telegraph Act in section 3 to mean any appliance, instrument, material or apparatus used or capable of use for transmission or reception of signs, signals, writing, images and sounds or intelligence of any nature by wire, visual or other electro-magnetic emissions, radio waves or Hertzian wave s, galvanic, electric or magnetic means.

Reliance was placed on rule 149 of the Telegraph Rules which states that it shall be lawful for the Telegraph Authority to monitor or intercept a message or messages transmitted through tele- phone, for the purpose of verification of any violation of these rules or for the maintenance of the equipment.

concepts.interpretation: Only Telegraph Authority can intercept, but not applicable here as police acted with consent
concepts.unlisted_description: Authority for monitoring by Telegraph Authority

anchor.surface_text: The tape recorded conversation is admissible provided first the conversation is relevant to the matters in issue secondly, there is identification of the voice and. thirdly, the accuracy of the tape recorded conversation is proved by eliminating the possibility of erasing the tape record.

anchor.surface_text: There is warrant for proposition that even if, evidence is illegally obtained it is admissible. holdings.text: There was no violation of the Indian Telegraph Act.

anchor.surface_text: There was no element of coercion or compulsion in attaching the tape recorder to the telephone. There was no violation of the Indian Telegraph Act. The High Court is in error ,on that point.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Police attached recorder with consent of Dr. Motwani, no damaging, tampering or touching of telegraph machinery; mere recording of voluntary conversation not interception under s25.

holdings.text: The tape recorded conversation is admissible in evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The tape recorded conversation is admissible in evidence.  1  1971 1 S C. R. 399.  2  1967 3 S.C.R. 720  3  1964 4 S.C.R. 733. It was said by counsel for the appellant that the tape

holdings.reasoning_summary: Conversation relevant, voices identified, accuracy proved by no erasure; follows precedents like Sri Rama Reddy, Yusufalli, Pratap Singh; admissible under Evidence Act ss7,8 as res gestae.

holdings.text: Even if evidence is illegally obtained it is admissible.

anchor.surface_text: There is warrant for proposition that even if, evidence is illegally obtained it is admissible. Over a century ago it was said in an English case where a constable searched the

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedents (Jones v Owen, Kurma, Magraj Patodia) hold relevant genuine evidence admissible regardless of means; judicial discretion only if unfair to accused, not here.

holdings.text: The admissibility of the tape recorded evidence [does not offend] Articles 20(3) and 21 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: It was said that the admissibility of the tape recorded evidence offended Articles 20 3  and 21 of the Constitution. The submission was that the manner of acquiring the tape

holdings.reasoning_summary: Conversation voluntary, no compulsion or self-incrimination under Art20(3); no unfair procedure under Art21; privacy not for guilty against anti-corruption.

holdings.text: There is no mischief of section 162 [CrPC].

anchor.surface_text: There is no mischief of section 162. The third contention was that the appellant did not attempt an offence. The conversation was said to show bargain. The evidence is that

holdings.reasoning_summary: s162 bars statements to police during investigation; here conversation between private parties Dr. Motwani and appellant, not to police.

holdings.text: These facts prove that the offence was committed.

anchor.surface_text: These facts prove that the offence was committed. The last contention on behalf of the appellant was that the sentence of imprisonment should be set aside in view of the

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tape and witness evidence corroborated; shows demand, bargaining, threat; facts establish attempt under ss161,385 IPC.

holdings.text: [Sentence not to be interfered with as] the gravity of the offence and the position held by the appellant at the relevant time do not merit such consideration.

anchor.surface_text: If it is said that the appellant had heart attacks and therefore the Court should take a lenient view about the sentence the gravity of the offence and the position held by

holdings.reasoning_summary: No sentence undergone; offence grave, appellant public servant (Coroner); fine paid irrelevant for custody sentence.

holdings.text: For these reasons, the appeal is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons, the appeal is dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All contentions rejected; evidence admissible, offence proved, sentence appropriate.

anchor.surface_text: Over a century ago it was said in an English case where a constable searched the appellant illegally and found a quantity of offending article in his pocket that it would be a dangerous obstacle to the administration of justice if it were held, because evidence was obtained by illegal means, it could not be used against a party charged with an offence. See Jones Owen 6 .

precedents.cited_proposition: evidence obtained by illegal means is admissible and it would be a dangerous obstacle to the administration of justice if it were held otherwise

precedents.citation: Kur ma, Son of Kanju R. 7

anchor.surface_text: The Judicial Committee in Kur ma, Son of Kanju R. 7  dealt with the conviction of an accused of being in unlawful possession of ammunition which had been discovered in consequence of a search of his person by a police officer below the rank of those who were permitted to make such searches.

precedents.cited_proposition: if evidence was admissible it matters not how it was obtained

anchor.surface_text: The admissibility of evidence procured in consequence of illegal searches and other unlawful acts was applied in. a recent English decision in R. v. Maqsud Ali 1 . In that case two persons suspected of murder went voluntarily with the Police Officers to a room in which, unknown to them, there was a microphone connected with a tape-recorder in another room.

precedents.cited_proposition: tape-recording of incriminating conversation obtained via hidden microphone is admissible
precedents.cited_holding: trial Judge correctly admitted the tape-recording

anchor.surface_text: As long as it is not tainted by an inadmissible confession of guilt evidence even if it is illegally obtained is admissible. There is no scope for holding that the appellant was made to incriminate himself. ... In R. v. Leatham 1  it was said It matters not how you get it if you steal it even, it would be admissible in evidence

precedents.cited_proposition: It matters not how you get it if you steal it even, it would be admissible in evidence

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons, the appeal is dismissed.
